revised_title: The Electrical Conductivity of Echinoderm Eggs and Its Implications for Fertilization and Artificial Parthenogenesis
tldr: This study investigates the electrical conductivity of echinoderm eggs and its relation to fertilization and artificial parthenogenesis. The author found that fertilized eggs have a higher electrical conductivity, indicating increased permeability to ions. This supports the theory that after fertilization, the egg surface becomes more permeable, playing a role in the development process.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Developmental Biology
